> whats the NK function?

Actually I think I misspoke slightly, I'm referring to an NK landscape. An
NK landscape is an approximation for the very rugged search spaces that
tend to come up in evolutionary search. N represents the number of genes
in a chromosome and K represents the number of linkages. So from this, we
know that K < N and the relative difficulty increases with K (as linkage
increases so does the number of peaks of the fitness landscape).

The fitness of a certain chromosome is determined by averaging the fitness
at each of the loci. The fitness of a locus is determined by a lookup
table (usually random) in which all combinations of alleles across K
linked loci are enumerated. Here is a quick example for N=3 K=1:

Locus one is linked to locus 2, locus 2 is linked to locus 3, and locus 3
is linked to locus 1.

A gene can take on either the value 0 or 1.

NK Table:

   locus1 locus2 locus3
00  this
01    table
10      is
11          random

Thus if locus one took on the value 0 and locus two took on the value 0,
the fitness of locus 1 would come from the table under (00, locus1). So
you can see, with a high linkage and a large number of genes... the
problem gets pretty difficult.

I read somewhere that NK landscapes are similar to the spin-glass model,
but I'm not sure about that.

-- 

Joseph Reisinger
